<a id="CubemapArray"></a>

# CubemapArray

**Inherits:** [ImageTextureLayered](ImageTextureLayered.md) **\<** [TextureLayered](TextureLayered.md) **\<** [Texture](Texture.md) **\<** [Resource](Resource.md) **\<** [RefCounted](RefCounted.md) **\<** [Object](Object.md)

An array of [Cubemap](Cubemap.md)\\ s, stored together and with a single reference.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

## Description

**CubemapArray**\\ s are made of an array of [Cubemap](Cubemap.md)\\ s. Like [Cubemap](Cubemap.md)\\ s, they are made of multiple textures, the amount of which must be divisible by 6 (one for each face of the cube).

The primary benefit of **CubemapArray**\\ s is that they can be accessed in shader code using a single texture reference. In other words, you can pass multiple [Cubemap](Cubemap.md)\\ s into a shader using a single **CubemapArray**. [Cubemap](Cubemap.md)\\ s are allocated in adjacent cache regions on the GPU, which makes **CubemapArray**\\ s the most efficient way to store multiple [Cubemap](Cubemap.md)\\ s.

Redot uses **CubemapArray**\\ s internally for many effects, including the [Sky](Sky.md) if you set [ProjectSettings.rendering/reflections/sky_reflections/texture_array_reflections](ProjectSettings.md#ProjectSettings_property_rendering/reflections/sky_reflections/texture_array_reflections) to ``true``.

To create such a texture file yourself, reimport your image files using the Redot Editor import presets. To create a CubemapArray from code, use [ImageTextureLayered.create_from_images()](ImageTextureLayered.md#ImageTextureLayered_method_create_from_images) on an instance of the CubemapArray class.

The expected image order is X+, X-, Y+, Y-, Z+, Z- (in Redot's coordinate system, so Y+ is "up" and Z- is "forward"). You can use one of the following templates as a base:

- [2Ã—3 cubemap template (default layout option)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Redot-Engine/redot-docs/master/tutorials/assets_pipeline/img/cubemap_template_2x3.webp)\ 

- [3Ã—2 cubemap template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Redot-Engine/redot-docs/master/tutorials/assets_pipeline/img/cubemap_template_3x2.webp)\ 

- [1Ã—6 cubemap template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Redot-Engine/redot-docs/master/tutorials/assets_pipeline/img/cubemap_template_1x6.webp)\ 

- [6Ã—1 cubemap template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Redot-Engine/redot-docs/master/tutorials/assets_pipeline/img/cubemap_template_6x1.webp)\ 

Multiple layers are stacked on top of each other when using the default vertical import option (with the first layer at the top). Alternatively, you can choose a horizontal layout in the import options (with the first layer at the left).

\ **Note:** **CubemapArray** is not supported in the Compatibility renderer due to graphics API limitations.
